name: Elaine Adams
comment info:
I have noticed (On the map and within the country) That the amount of Trump supporters, in reality, was larger than we ever could have thought. There seems to be a huge backlash each time Trump says or does something, which I took to mean there was a small support for trump. But I know realize it is because the Trump supporters have no need to go out on social media and defend their beliefs since they already got what they wanted. A republican in office. And if they back down from this they will have to admit they made a mistake. And they wouldn't  do that would they?

I wonder how the area the voters live in affects their voting. Maybe an adult version of peer pressure? There are many “voter islands” and most of them are for Republicans. I wonder why that is.

“A republican age” As more millenials and gen Z children come of voting age, the support for a more liberal or democratic government continues to grow. However, many of the older generations continue to vote Republican. It is unclear why, but the fact that the Democratic candidate was a woman, the wife of a past president, and had discrepancies in their statements through interviews and speeches(though Donald Trump has many of his own), may play a role in this. Hopefully as more of the younger Americans come of voting age, elections will be, not a way to keep the country in one place but rather, a vote for the candidate that will help us move forward.

replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Elaine Adams.
Some of the student responses mention that though most of the area of the map voted from Trump, that does not mean that most of the voters voted for Trump.  They talked about population density.  Taking both geographic area and population density into account, what additional conjectures do you have?

replies.comment info: HI, @Easton Vander Stoep.  You hit it on the head that maps can be kind of deceptive.  They show geographic area and not the population.  There is a type of map called a cartogram that  shows the distribution of population rather than geographic area.

name: Liv
comment info: Something that stands out to me right away about this graph is the dominated by the color red, which I had not been expecting. I wonder why the map is so predominantly red, even when the presidential race was so close last year. When you take a closer look, the Northeastern regions (where I live) there is much less red than other portions of the country. This shows that I am living in a “political bubble”, and this graph expands my political knowledge outside of my region. Another thing that I noticed was that costal areas have more blue than land locked states, on average. I am curious to the reasoning behind this.

replies.comment info: Hi, @ Liv.  I wonder other items you noticed in the graph.  Have you checked out the map that gives you percentile statistics on your neighbors and the country?  You can find it athttps://tinyurl.com/2016Neighbors.  Please share with us what you discover.

name: Will
comment info: Something I noticed was that Trump seems to win by a landslide based of area of influence alone, because almost all of the map is painted red in his support. I know however, that he lost the popular vote by a little bit, which means that a large majority of the population must live in these smaller, more liberal areas. Despite this, I wonder how nearly half of the country can live in such a small area. I know California is by far the most populous state, but areas like Northeast Arizona and Northwest New Mexico surprised me because they do not strike me as being particularly populated nor in favor of Hillary. I also wonder why the blue areas are so separated while the red areas are much more conjoined. A title for this graph could be "Half is Less Than You Think." My idea behind this title is that the blue represents about half of the nation, and yet it doesn't appear to be close to half of 350 million people. The article could go into voting statistics and explain why this graph might appear inaccurate. That is what I think is going on in this map.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Will.  
Your headline “Half is Less Than You Think” nicely summarizes your thoughts on how the percentage of the geographic area and percentage of votes can vary – Republicans got more of the area, but less of the votes, whereas Democrats received more of the votes but less of the area.  
You may want to look at yesterday’s midterm election results for the House of Representatives (https://tinyurl.com/2018ByDistrict), and compare it to the 2016 presidential results.  Is there a comparable relationship?  Keep noticing and wondering!

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to “What’s Going On in This Graph?” and the Wednesday moderation.  Today’s graph is a heat map showing the voting results from the 2016 presidential election by U. S. voting precincts. 
For comparison, you can look at this national map detailing 2018 House election results (https://tinyurl.com/2018ByDistrict).  
And you can see how your area (https://tinyurl.com/2016ByPrecinct) or even neighbors (https://tinyurl.com/2016Neighbors) voted in 2016 by entering any address, ZIP code, or town or city.  
Study the maps and statistics and, from 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, give us your responses online to these three questions. (On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the articles that included these graphs and much more.) 

	What do you NOTICE in these graphs? 

	What do you WONDER? What are you curious about?

	What’s GOING ON in these graphs? 
Write a catchy headline that captures the graphs’ main idea.  If your headline makes a claim, tell us what you noticed that supports your claim.

The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order. Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with the headline.

Then, read some responses. Click on "Reply" to an interesting response to get a discussion going. Learn different perspectives when you read what other students have to say about your response. 

We look forward to reading your discoveries.

name: Ned
comment info: The first thing I noticed about this graph is that red completely dominates the entire country. But, in my town, and on the east coast of Massachusetts in general, Hilary Clinton had the majority of the votes. In my precinct in particular, she had 52% of the votes, while Trump only had 39% of the votes. Massachusetts appears to be the state with the highest percentage of Hilary supporters, and New England in general seems to be the region that supports Hilary the most. But, while all counties in Massachusetts voted the majority for Hilary Clinton, there are some towns that voted for Trump. In fact, in one of the towns adjacent to my own, Donald Trump received 52% of the votes. This leads me to wonder how two towns that are so close and so similar can have completely different outcomes in their election results. I also wondered how the election was so close considering most of the map was red. The answer to that question, I realized, was that many of the most densely populated cities in the country voted for Hilary, while many sparsely populated areas voted for Trump. If I were to come up with a title for this graph, it would be “Why the Colors May Not Tell the Whole Story,” because this graph does not appear to be an accurate representation of how close the election was.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Teachers told us that they wanted to see the graphs sooner so there is more time to lesson plan.  Here is the revised schedule for “What’s Going On In This Graph?”.   
Thursday afternoons:  Release the graph for the following week.
Wednesday 9 am – 2 pm ET:  Live moderation
Thursday afternoon:  Reveal the article, additional questions, and the Stat Nuggets
Our next live moderation will be Wednesday, November 14.  It will be released on Thursday, November 8.
Please note that there will be no “What’s Going On In This Graph?” on Wednesday, November 21.  Happy Thanksgiving.

name: Dray
comment info:
I notice that there seems to be a lot more red areas than blue, which could represent the population of a certain group of people.

I wonder why there isn't as much of a split between red and blue and I wonder what the actual key is behind the colors. I also wonder why there is a some white space as well. 

Because this graph is so close to the mid term elections, I think it has to do something with republican and democratic parties and which is obviously more predominant (republican). I think the white is independent as well. I think this graph represents who is registered as what party to vote. 
Title: A Whole Lotta Red

replies.comment info: Thank you, @Dray for responding so early in the morning after a long night with yesterday's midterm election.  You noticed about more red areas that blue areas in the 2016 presidential election voting results.  Maps show geography and land mass.  I wonder how the populations of the red and blue areas compare.  Do the red areas have more population than the blue areas?  You may want to take a look at the voting results from last night’s midterm elections (https://tinyurl.com/2018ByDistrict).  How do the red areas compare in the two graphs – 2016 presidential election and 2018 midterm for House of Representatives?

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Dray  I also noticed the same things, and was also curious as to what the whites portions were meant to represent. I would agree that the white is showing the independent  areas.

name: Oliver
comment info: Where I live, Hampstead, New Hampshire, voting follows the national trend in supporting Trump. In my town, 58% of voters or 3,186 people voted for Donald Trump while 36% of voters or 1,996 people voted for Hilary Clinton. However, if you travel south for about 20 minutes, the area begins to favor Hilary Clinton by a larger majority. In Lawrence, Massachusetts, where a large population of Hispanic and Black voters lives, Hilary is favored to 86% over Trump’s 10%. My question is this: should we consider the electoral college outdated? Wouldn’t it make sense for majority votes to dictate the outcome of elections? This map is meant to physically illustrate how the country tended to vote during the 2016 Presidential Election. The discoloration on the graph is there to indicate which states, regions, and towns voted for which primary candidate, and how popular the candidate is in the recorded data.   If I was to create a title for the map shown, “America Is More Purple Than We Are Led to Believe” seems to be the most fitting. Since popular vote was in favor of Clinton (by a small margin), but the electoral college votes tilted towards Trump, America is in a time of political separation; there are seemingly equal amounts of people that support each candidate in each party, it’s just that distribution of the votes that create a majority “red” map.

replies.comment info: Good morning, @Oliver.  You bring up a very interesting concern – “Should we consider the Electoral College outdated?” We don’t see anything in this map about the Electoral College, but could you use the information they show to support your position on the Electoral College?  A map produced from the results of last night’s midterm elections (https://tinyurl.com/2018ByDistrict) may be helpful to your claim.  @Oliver

name: Grant
comment info: What first noticed about the map and specifically where I live is the fact almost all the neighboring precincts including mine were all dominated by Clinton. In my precinct, Clinton had 52% of the votes whereas Trump only had about 39%. At first, I was shocked to see to all the different areas of the countries and which were primarily Trump voters and which were Clinton votes. However, after focusing on my area alone, it did not shock me to see and large imbalance in voters in support of Clinton. I begin to wonder what exactly this graph would show if the data was from like 2000 election or even father back. Would the demographics change significantly of would it be primality based on the candidates. If I had to give this graph a name, I think I would name it "A Sea of Red" because at first glance, the map seems to show an overwhelming amount of red across the states almost like one big body of water...but it's instead of a blue sea its red.

replies.comment info: I see that you responded 11 hours ago – about 10 pm last night.  Elections in Massachusetts had been called by then.  If you go to the map for yesterday’s midterm elections (https://tinyurl.com/2018ByDistrict), you’ll see how your area voted.  Has it changed from 2016?  Maybe it still has gone Democratic, but has the percentage changed?  Also, the detailed map (https://tinyurl.com/2016ByPrecinct) tells you how far away is the area that voted differently than your precinct did.  Has this area changed?

replies.name: I
replies.comment info: @Grant I am seeing the exact same thing in my area. Vacaville seems to be most dominated by Clinton supporters. It was surprising to see how divided the voters were and I had been expecting more of a mix.  However, I would change the name to "The Blue Sea" because there is a lot of neighboring cities and counties that are surprising to me as well

name: Erin
comment info: The first thing I noticed was how dominant the color red was. It seems as though the majority of the people in the U.S. are Republicans, but that's not true. One can see that the East Coast and the West Coast have a more dominant presence of the color blue than the rest of the country, as well as lower Texas and parts of New Mexico, where it is obvious that there are a good amount of Democratic supporters. As you zoom in, I think it's important to see that there are parts of the states that seem to be in complete support of the Republican, which was Trump at the time, that are in support of Hilary who was the Democratic campaigner. I wonder why the creators of the map decided to make a state completely red, even when there were cities within that state that were blue. I think it's important to not only show a state's majority but also the minority. I also wonder why the East Coast and the West Coast favored Hilary and the rest of the country supported Trump. What factors were involved? Was religion involved? If it was, does one specific religion only support one side? As I zoom in to where I live, my town and the surrounding area is mostly blue. As you get closer to NH it becomes predominately red. I live on the border of MA and NH, so my town voted 48% (Trump) and 42% (Hilary). It's interesting to see how the closer you get to certain states, the more the votes vary and favor one campaigner over the other. My headline would be, "The Truth Lies Beneath the Tip of the Iceberg"

name: Abigail
comment info: The first thing I noticed when I first looked at the map was that it appears that the red areas, which are areas that voted Republican, seem to dominate the map of the country. Then my eye started to gravitate towards the Massachusetts area and I noticed that it was blue, and the states directly North and South of Massachusetts seem to create this blue line down the Eastern coast of the country that stops and curves above Florida and continues West until Alabama. I began looking for other blue areas and I noticed that the West coast (California and Washington) seems to follow a similar trend, skipping over Oregon. I then searched for how my town and the surrounding towns voted and found that they mostly voted for Clinton, with my town divided 63% for Clinton and 27% for Trump. The map showed me that the closest Trump area to my town was Peabody, about a 17-minute drive away. It was interesting to see how my town voted compared to the state and to the entire country. Something that I wondered was how the election results were so close when the map seems to depict such a large gap between Trump voters and Clinton voters. If I were to write a headline for this map, it would be “The Importance of Zooming in on the Bigger Picture” because the story this map is telling is that Trump swept the country, however in reality we know that the win was actually quite narrow.

replies.comment info: Good morning, @Abigail.  You say that  “the story this map is telling is that Trump swept the country, however in reality we know that the win was actually quite narrow” and from this you propose the headline “The Importance of Zooming in on the Bigger Picture.”  Right on!  How about zooming in some more and noticing where this is true?  I wonder if there are characteristics of these areas.  Let us know what you discover.

name: Isabel
comment info: What I noticed about the map is that the area that I live in voted more for Clinton than for Trump. My small town was entirely blue but we were bordered by one specific red area. I looked through the map as a whole I noticed the the country overall, was mostly red but there were many blue counties sprinkled throughout. As I was skimming the map I also noticed that the counties with higher population density usually voted for Clinton and the counties with lower population density voted for Trump. I wonder why population density has such a strange affect on the overall votes from the specific counties? The story this map is telling is the votes of the counties are influenced greatly by population density.  A good title for the graph could be, ”A Country Divided by Density"

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Isabel.  I wonder if getting elected is about geographic area or population density?  You’ve started the ball rolling on this.  Maybe others in your class or online can add to this discussion.
Also, take a look at last night’s midterm results athttps://tinyurl.com/2018ByDistrict.  I wonder if the voting results for your area change from 2016 to 2018. (You’ll notice that the 2016 map is by precinct and the 2018 map is by House of Representative district, so you’ll have to qualify your analysis.)

name: Gabrielle Mazow
comment info: When I first opened the map I immediately said, "Wow...I had no idea that much of the country voted Republican."  I noticed that Democratic voters were a rarity which suprised me because the majoirty of people who surround me are Democratic.  This proves that I do live in a political bubble because I was surprised to see the map the way it is.  As the map zoomed into my town, Swampscott, MA, it got overwhelmingly more blue.  My town voted 62% for Clinton and 30% for Trump.  This did not surprise me at all and neither did the fact that most of the surrounding cities were blue as well.   I wonder what factors lead to most of the coastlines voting Democratically and if this is a reocurring theme throughout presedential elections.  I'm also curious to see this map next to the prior presedential elections and analyze some factors that made the country shift so drastically.  If I were to create a headline to describe this map I would go with "The Blue Undertow" because it encapsulates the phenomenon that when looking at the map zoomed out it is almost completely red but as you zoom in, especially to my area, it gets more and more blue.  This also calls to mind the fact that Clinton won the popular vote and as one zooms in, they can more easily comprehend how that happened.

name: Kathryn
comment info: What I first noticed about the map was that the majority of the country was red or voted Republican. In addition, the midwest heavily voted Republican, while the coasts were more Democratic.  My city, Beverly, Massachusetts, voted 65% for Clinton and 29% for Trump, and most of the surrounding counties voted Democratic as well. I wonder why the race was so close when the map is so red. I think this because, while the Midwest voted Republican, overall, bigger and heavily populated cities like New York, Los Angelas, Chicago, and Boston voted Democrat, while the majority of the rest of the country voted Republican. I’m also curious why there are areas of blue in the South-West near New Mexico and Arizona and in the South near Alabama and Missippi, I wonder if the votes in these areas are affected by the demographics of the area, perhaps race or socioeconomic class. An interesting title would be: “Blue Cities, Red Country”

replies.comment info: @Kathryn, thank you for the snappy headline “Blue Cities, Red Country.”  I wonder if you can find any “blue” precincts that are not cities.  To do this, go to the “extremely detailed” map (https://tinyurl.com/2016ByPrecinct) and click on “Visit a Random Voter Island.”  I wonder if there are characteristics of these areas.

name: Colby
comment info: I noticed that my state, Massachusetts, is one of the only states that is mostly blue. Although there is some red, my town, Marblehead, is all blue. The map shows that 61% of my town voted for Clinton and 3% voted for Trump. I wonder why a very large majority of the map is red even though it was a very tight race. I believe this is because the places that are blue are urban populations and therefore have a much larger population so there will be more votes and more electoral college votes. I also believe that many of the red states like in the middle of the country have a significantly low population so their votes won’t matter as much and they will have less electoral college votes. I wonder what the map looked like from the 2012 election when a Barack Obama, a Democrat, won. A title for this graph could be “The Colors May Be Misleading”.

name: Sarah Faulkner
comment info: I notice that in terms of surface area, the map is predominantly red. However, regions around large cities are almost mostly blue. I notice that my city, Beverly entirely blue, and that the Cove, the part of Beverly that I live in is in the 72nd percentile for Clinton. Also it interesting to me that some bordering cities are different colors and I wonder what aspects like racial makeup of a region or socioeconomic divide cause this shift. I am curious about the two larger areas of blue on the map; in the southwest region and in the south near Alabama. The latter is particularly shocking because it is commonly known as the “bible belt” so one would expect this region to be more conservative. If I had to write a headline for this map, it would be “the Blue Lining.” I would name it this because the amount of red on the map is daunting but the blue is prominent in all of the cities. Additionally, I know that Clinton won the popular vote. The story the map is telling us is that this map is exemplary of the flaws in American voting systems and how the electoral college has the power to overturn the majority in our democracy.

name: Lily
comment info: It is interesting to see this zoomed out view of the country to better understand the spread of votes for each party. I observed that the coastal communities are, on average, more left leaning while the middle of the country is further right. However, prior to zooming in, it is important to note that the entire country did appear to be red before I zoomed in. This shows that the country is mostly made up of Republicans, which makes sense due to the fact that we have a Republican president currently. The region that I live in, and its surrounding areas, however, are very blue. The spread of political views could possibly be determined by variables pertaining to resources in certain parts of the country or arts and religious beliefs that are more popular in some areas than others. I wonder if these different beliefs could sway political views.

name: Lily
comment info:
As I look closely at the interactive map, I notice that primarily the country is red, but when you zoom in closely to where I live it is mostly blue.  Also, it is interesting to see that some neighboring towns, cities, or states are colored differently.  For example, it was a landslide for Clinton in Lawrence, but in Pelham, NH Trump won by a majority.  Other suburban towns, like my hometown, Andover,  voted for Clinton, but not as strongly.   I cannot help but wonder why these  communities voted so differently given their geographic proximity.   Is it related to average income, presence of children, average age, ethnic background?  The map coloring does not tell the full story.  Also, I'm curious how this map changed during the course of the election related to polling.  Was it accurate?  And how did the Democratic/Republic vote in this election compare with last presidential election.  Did people vote candidates or party?  This map does not give a good representation and the color coding is misleading to what happened during the election because we know it was roughly equal during the time of the election

"Colors Don't Tell the True Story"

name: Elise Costello
comment info: According to the New York Times “An Extremely Detailed Map of the 2016 Election”, the region where I live in Marblehead, Massachusetts, is clearly a “Clinton precinct”, with 61% of the 1,858 total votes for Hillary, and only 31% of the votes for Trump. It interests me that more coastal areas such as Marblehead, Beverly, and Manchester contain the most Hillary supporters. The nearest “Trump Precinct” to me is in South Peabody, which is further inland. I can’t help but wonder why there is a greater amount of Hillary supporters on the coast. This trend pertains to more than the New England north shore - it can be seen along the coast of California as well. Perhaps the voting trends relate to the demographics of people who inhabit certain areas of the country. After all, citizens from different areas of the US are bound to want different things from their president due to the geographical, social, and economic landscapes that surround them. I would like to know what these general, regionally determined desires might be. Overall, this map exhibits that  US citizens of the middle states were all in favor of Trump, possibly because his campaign arguably promised more social, political, and economic change than Hillary's did. If I was to create a headline for what this map displays, I would probably title it “Middle States Vote In Favor of Change”, due to the previously mentioned connotations of Trump's campaign.

name: Sofia
comment info:
Although my state looks predominantly red, in my zip code area it was heavily blue. I noticed that traditionally red states, such as Texas and Florida, are mostly red, but even states that lean more Democrat, like California and New York, look mostly red on this map. I am not sure if that is just how the map is formatted or if these states really did change their tune during this election.

I wonder if this is how a normally "half and half" map looks, since everyone said the election was close. I also wonder what the rural to urban population ratio is. If more city folks moved out into the country, creating more suburban areas, would the map be colored differently?

An interesting headline might be: "Should a seemingly blue and red America be colored in shades of purple?"

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Sofia.
You noticed a “voter island” – a precinct or area that votes differently than the surrounding precincts.  If you go to the “extremely detailed” map (https://tinyurl.com/2016ByPrecinct) and click on “Visit a Random Voter Island,” you will see an assortment of precincts nationwide that are like yours, surrounded by precincts that vote differently.  I wonder what characteristics these precincts have?  I wonder how the number of voting islands has changed in the recent past?

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Sofia I had the same observation that the Southern states are red probably due to the shared views they have with Trump because most Southern states are interest in prejudice against race. I feel like even if city folk were to into the country the views woudnt change due to values.

name: Jett
comment info:
I noticed that in the 2016 election, Donald Trump had the majority of the country's support. When I went into my zip code, just about everyone supported Hillary Clinton with some Trump supporters by me in the Borough Park area. I also noticed that a majority of metropolitan areas even in the south and some midwest states were more Democratic compared to the surrounding suburban and rural areas. Cities like Dallas and Atlanta had support within its city limits but extending out of the city is a sea of red signifying Trump's support. This is also the case in other bigger Texas cities as well as cities in the Plains like Oklahoma City or Des Moines. 

I wonder why this is the case. Why are the metropolitan, bigger cities voting Democratic especially in Republican heavy regions like the Plains and the South where I can see why they support him. 

Catchy headline: "Democrats Dominate the Metropolitan"

replies.comment info:
@Jett@Jett, I see that you responded to the release before yesterday’s midterm election.  If you take a look at the midterm results athttps://tinyurl.com/2018ByDistrict, I wonder if the voting results for your area changed from 2016 to 2018. (You’ll notice that the 2016 map is by precinct and the 2018 map is by House of Representative district, so you’ll have to qualify your analysis.)  Are any cities in the country changing their voting pattern?
Keep noticing, wondering, and sharing your conjectures.

name: Chris
comment info:
I noticed that the majority of the map is red and there are only very few parts where there is blue support.  The few places where there is blue appear to be on the outside of the country and the middle has less.  

I wonder why there is more red than blue shown on the map even though the true split is around half blue and half red?

A headline could be: "Is the US really split Red and Blue?"

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: I do agree that majority of the map is marked with a lot of red as to there only being a few blue. The red seemed to be more located in the southern states.  @Chris

name: Dakota
comment info:
I noticed that geographically, Trump has the support of most of the country. When I focused on my zip code, a majority of my city and surrounding area supported the Democrats. As I look at the southern and mid-western states, it was mostly Republican.

I wonder why many cities vote Democrat while more rural and suburban areas vote Republican.

A catchy headline could be "Despite media predictions, Trump dominates Presidential Election"

replies.name: F
replies.comment info: Go Hillary where is russia????
